qas.question: Who created the account of Jesus?
Who amended the account at a later date?
What prompts darkness over the land in old literary works?

answers.text: the death of kings and other major figures

qas.question: What ethnicity are these literary works mostly?
Who describes the idea of an eclipse as totally wrong?
What does Philo believe those who take the image of darkness literally are doing?
What prompted Philo to become a writer?
What did Philo not intend to happen after someone read his writings?
What group of readers would have read works by Geza Vermes?

context: Modern biblical scholarship treats the account in the synoptic gospels as a literary creation by the <a0_0>author of the Mark Gospel<a0_0/>, amended in the <a1_0>Luke<a1_0/> and Matthew accounts, intended to heighten the importance of what they saw as <b6_0>a theologically significant event<b6_0/>, and not intended <b7_0>to be taken literally<b7_0/>. This image of darkness over the land would have been understood by <b9_0>ancient readers<b9_0/>, a typical element in the description of <a2_0>the death of kings and other major figures<a2_0/> by writers such as Philo, Dio Cassius, Virgil, Plutarch and Josephus. <a4_0>Géza Vermes<a4_0/> describes the darkness account as typical of "<a3_0><b8_0>Jewish<b8_0/><a3_0/> eschatological imagery of the day of the Lord", and says that those interpreting it as a datable eclipse are <b5_0>"barking up the wrong tree"<b5_0/>.
